Having seen some artists shift towards generated images in several ways and being purposefully deceitful about it, many people are now hypervigilant. 

This has been triggering witch hunts, which is sad and horrible for any innocent artists caught in the crossfire. It happened to someone I know. :/
Oooh it cuts the composition a bit, but I quite like the dark cape! I suppose the one you should pick will depend on what element you want to see standing out?

Image generators are fostering a climate of distrust, after all. I assume these people mean well, and their lack of discernment isn't malicious... but it show us how little most people understand of the craft at times, even among allies.

To err is human. I hope we can learn to trust again, in time.

There’s a real underlying reason a lot of your favorite artists are returning, even to dip, to traditional media. I think we’re dying to tap back in with why we do what we do and that’s a good place to remember. The joy of touching, practice, learning, taking a LOT of time, having time to ask why

I want more people to consider what art means to them without the pressure to impress. How does your hand like to mark a curve? Where does it apply pressure and where does it release? What sorts of shapes are you drawn to? Do you hold your breath when you draw a delicate straight line?

Well, the pandemic & what ensued have been earth-shattering moments! It takes some time to recover from stuff like this. The world hasn't really bounced back, it's pretty normal to still feel out of it. Been exhausted myself, I have to say! :')

Whatever you do, try to be kind to yourself.

It looks astonishingly like this emote I used to use:

°__°

“The LAION-5B machine learning dataset used by Google, Stable Diffusion, and other major AI products has been removed by the organization that created it after a Stanford study found that it contained 3,226 suspected instances of child sexual abuse material, 1,008 of which were externally validated”

Sounds like it could be some form of burn-out creeping in. :/ So much has been going on at large these past few years that it's not too surprising. I hope you'll manage to get back to a point you're happy with! And in the meantime, don't be too hard on yourself. Ups & downs are completely normal. 💖

That's how I draw lines for my traditional paintings too! I sketch on paper, line them digitally, print the lines, and trace them on my watercolour paper. There's no "right" way to go about it! Just do things in a way that feels right to you.

Very glad our chat could be of help. :D

Well, creatives gotta create, no matter how! I've tried writing, printmaking, acrylagouache, handmade paper, designing and sowing a bat doll pattern... but I do like having a few go-to techniques to specialise in, too. Sadly, as an art control freak, I'm upset one of 'em had to be watercolours 😂

I'm glad you have a happy place with your traditional tools, at least!

You know what, there may be one positive thing about the A;I boom: it made me double down on my trad art. 😂 They can't take our originals away!
(I just noticed the typo, my bad)

For me, it's linework! I used to struggle so much with it. I had no idea how to make it work until I realised my brain needed it to treat it like a clean pencil sketch and ignore all notions of "solid black line".

I can relate! 😩 Digital art is much less of a hassle, but I'm never quite happy with how artificial it ends up looking... I always sketch traditionally, even if I do my linework or painting with PS.

I hope you'll find a way to make it more comfortable and organic!

That's really sweet! :D I did have fun drawing oranges back in the day, too.

Food in art can be so challenging. It reminds me of Studio Ghibli, they make their dishes look positively mouth-watering...
The things we're struggling with most can sometimes become so integral to our process, it's fascinating!
Tell me, which art things where you least expecting to really get into? (Can be a medium, technique, tools, etc)
I recommend Skyfeed if you're interested in making your own!

Keeping sketches for yourself is liberating and much healthier!

I really dislike how Internet culture has normalised making everything we do into a spectacle to share online. Taking time off is important.

I wonder how many people genuinely think that artists don't routinely fail at things. Like, start writing a story and it doesn't work out and you put it in 'the file'. Noodle around with a piece of music and decide it's not a thing. I assure you - artists fail constantly. It's a big part of the gig.

So torn about hot press watercolour paper.

- Fluid100
Pros: Great layering, bright clean colours.
Cons: Tears w/ blu-tac, masking fluid, erasing.

- Arches
Pros: Tougher, erases & layers well, ubiquitous
Cons: Warps. Something about the final texture irks me, too
